author: djrtwo
content: The protocol randomly requests pieces of data for some duration from random vals. This is to ensure they keep it for that duration or take on counter party risk to get rid of it

author: djrtwo
content: This is to ensure the data does not disappear quickly and honest vals that custody could  be used for reconstruction of missing data

author: djrtwo
content: But the protocol does not mandate they serve it

author: trent_vanepps
content: is there any consideration for making this mandated with small penalties? if it's crucial to network operation, shouldn't it be?

author: potuz
content: Is there a method to enforce this? I can't imagine how to do it. Similarly now, the only penalty for not serving blocks is that your peers downscore you and they block you. But eventually you find others

author: djrtwo
content: But you can use a dht construction in which your peerid dictates a subset of samples you must serve for some time

author: djrtwo
content: And can be downscored for not doing so

author: potuz
content: I guess it can be enforced if the call is through the protocol. I require some data sampling that validator x is supposed to have now. I send a signed message requesting this sample. A proposer includes the message in a block. The validator needs to submit that data in the next few blocks or be slashed

author: djrtwo
content: Right, but thats not an effective way to retrieve lost data. Nor could all data be retrieved that way on chain (assumption of shardin). The random challenges help here but not really on data retrieval
